questions.question: I don't like ....................... of my physics teachers.
questions.description: Not either means the same as neither. The sentence given above can also be written as: I like neither of my physics teachers.

questions.question: ........................... people don't trust politicians.
questions.description: We use most of before a pronoun or a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: Neither .......................................... the door.
questions.description: After either and neither we use a singular noun and a singular verb.

questions.question: Neither of .......................................... valid.
questions.description: After neither of, we use a plural noun and a singular verb.

questions.question: ....................... the shops are closed on Sundays.
questions.description: We use most before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: They spend ........................... their income on movies.
questions.description: We can leave out of after all, both and half.

questions.question: ................................. my friends wished me on my birthday.
.................................. his ideas are quite interesting.
questions.description: We can leave out 'of' after all when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: ................................ my children are engineers.
questions.description: We can leave out 'of' after both when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: His ideas are ............................ different from those of his peers.
The new job isn't ............................... different from the old one.
